Authors: Kersters I., Van Vooren L., Huys G., Janssen P., Kersters K., Verstraet W.
Title: Influence of temperature and process technology on the occurrence of Aeromonas species and hygienic indicator organisms in drinking water production plants
Affiliations: Centre of Environmental Sanitation, University of Gent, Coupure Links 653, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Department of Applied Mathematics, Biometrics and Process Control, University of Gent, Coupure Links 653, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Laboratory of Microbiology, University of Gent, K.-L. Ledeganckstraat 35, Gent, B-9000, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Kersters, I., Centre of Environmental Sanitation, University of Gent, Coupure Links 653, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Van Vooren, L., Department of Applied Mathematics, Biometrics and Process Control, University of Gent, Coupure Links 653, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Huys, G., Laboratory of Microbiology, University of Gent, K.-L. Ledeganckstraat 35, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Janssen, P., Laboratory of Microbiology, University of Gent, K.-L. Ledeganckstraat 35, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Kersters, K., Laboratory of Microbiology, University of Gent, K.-L. Ledeganckstraat 35, Gent, B-9000, Belgium; Verstraet, W., Centre of Environmental Sanitation, University of Gent, Coupure Links 653, Gent, B-9000, Belgium
Abstract: The occurrence of Aeromonas spp. and hygienic indicator organisms in raw and treated waters of five drinking water production plants in Flanders (Belgium) was surveyed over a period of 17 months. Aeromonads were isolated on ampicillin-dextrin agar (ADA) and further identified by gas-liquid chromatographic analysis of their cellular fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) content. ADA medium was found to be highly specific for the enumeration of Aeromonas spp. In general, Aeromonas counts were very low in untreated groundwater but numbered 104–106 colony-forming units per liter in open storage reservoirs for surface water. Aeromonas spp. were seasonally distributed with maximal densities occurring during the summer. The ecology of Aeromonas in the different waters was studied in relation to the physical, chemical, and microbiological water characteristics. Strongly positive correlations were observed between Aeromonas densities and heterotrophic plate counts, whereas a clearly negative relationship was found with dissolved oxygen. On average, 99.7% of the aeromonads were removed by flocculation-decantation followed by breakpoint chlorination, whereas 98.9% were removed by slow sand filtration. Flocculation-decantation without breakpoint chlorination did not reduce the microbial numbers. At three of four drinking water production plants tested, rapid sand filtration decreased the number of aeromonads and hygienic indicator organisms. At one plant, however, the numbers of Aeromonas and hygienic indicator organisms were high in the sand filter effluents. Increased numbers of aeromonads were also counted in the effluent of the activated carbon filters. Hence, inactivation of Aeromonas spp. by the current process technology appears not sufficient to exclude postchlorination. The survival of aeromonads in certain filter systems may be due to the growth of these bacteria on biodegradable organic material, provided by the decomposition from bacteria, algae, or other sources. © 1995, Springer-Verlag New York Inc. All rights reserved.

Authors: Hespanhol I., Prost A.M.E.
Title: Who guidelines and national standards for reuse and water quality
Affiliations: Division of Environmental Health, World Health Organization, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland; WHO Office at the European Economic Community, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Hespanhol, I., Division of Environmental Health, World Health Organization, CH-1211 Geneva, Switzerland; Prost, A.M.E., WHO Office at the European Economic Community, Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: Guidelines for reuse and drinking water quality are based on scientific research and epidemiological findings, and as such provide guidance for making risk management decisions related to the protection of public health and the preservation of the environment. Water quality standards are legal impositions enacted by means of laws, regulations or technical procedures, which are established by countries by adapting guidelines to their national priorities and taking in account their technical, economical, social, cultural and political characteristics and constraints. Several examples are presented with the objective of differentiating standards from guidelines, and to show how countries have been adapting WHO guidelines to their situations in order to produce national standards on drinking water quality, and for the use of treated wastewater for crop irrigation. © 1993.
Author Keywords: drinking water treatment; guidelines; standards; wastewater reuse; wastewater treatment; water quality

Authors: Peeters M., Hiele M., Ghoos Y., Huysmans V., Geboes K., Vantrappen G., Rutgeerts P.
Title: Test conditions greatly influence permeation of water soluble molecules through the intestinal mucosa: Need for standardisation
Affiliations: Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Department of Gastroenterology, University Hospital of Gasthuisberg, University of Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Peeters, M., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Hiele, M., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Ghoos, Y., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Huysmans, V., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Geboes, K., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Vantrappen, G., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium; Rutgeerts, P., Centre for GI Research, University of Leuven, Belgium, Department of Gastroenterology, University Hospital of Gasthuisberg, University of Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Permeability tests are widely used to investigate the pathogenesis of various gastrointesrinal diseases including coeliac disease, infectious diarrhoea, and inflammatory bowel disease. In Crohn's disease they are used as activity parameters by some investigators. Lack of standardisation, however, makes it very difficult to compare data reported in different studies. The aim of this study was to gather permeation data in well controlled test conditions to standardise the methods. Nine healthy volunteers each received five consecutive permeability tests by mouth using polyethylene glycol-400 (PEG-400) and 51Cr-EDTA as probe molecules. The probes were dissolved in water, a glucose solution, a starch solution, a hyperosmolar lactulose-mannitol solution, and a liquid meal. A significantly decreased permeation for both probes was found when given with the hyperosmolar solution. The 51Cr-EDTA permeation was also decreased with water. The permeability index, 51Cr-EDTA/PEG-400, corrected for influencing factors, confirmed that the lactulose-mannitol solution and plain water yield lower values of macromolecule permeation than starch, glucose or liquid meal. Hyperosmolarity was clearly accompanied by a decrease in permeability probably caused by reversed solvent drag. Interindividual variability of probe permeation and permeability index is very low with a standard liquid meal. It is proposed that for permeability studies a standard Liquid meal is always used.
Index Keywords: edetate chromium cr 51; macrogol 400; adult; article; female; human; intestine mucosa; male; normal human; oral drug administration; permeability; priority journal; standardization

Authors: Loutz J.M., Peeters S., Lindekens L.
Title: Radiation-curable water-borne systems
Affiliations: Speciality Chemicals Div, Drogenbos, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Loutz, J.M., Speciality Chemicals Div, Drogenbos, Belgium; Peeters, S., Speciality Chemicals Div, Drogenbos, Belgium; Lindekens, L., Speciality Chemicals Div, Drogenbos, Belgium
Abstract: Water-dilutable radcure formulations offer new possibilities for the use of this technology because they allow a reduction in the thickness of a coating without making use of low molecular weight unsaturated diluents or organic solvents. The UV-induced polymerisation appears to be a very interesting technique in the case of pigment printing because the replacement of a condensation process gives rise to the evolution of by-products by a polymerisation mechanism without any liberation of volatiles and allows the achievement of higher productivity and better performance.
Index Keywords: Coating techniques; Crosslinking; Curing; Screen printing; Textile finishing; Pigment printing; Unsaturated diluents; Water-borne inks; Textile printing; coating; curing, radiation, ultraviolet; polymerization; printing, pigment
Correspondence Address: Loutz, J.M.; Speciality Chemicals Div, Drogenbos, Belgium

Authors: Provost F., Nieuwenhuysen P.
Title: Measuring overlap of data bases in water supply and sanitation using sampling and the binomial probability distribution
Affiliations: University Library, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Provost, F., University Library, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, Brussel, 1050, Belgium; Nieuwenhuysen, P.
Abstract: A quick and easy method is presented to estimate the overlap of data bases, which can be used to assist the data base producers and managers in their policy towards coverage of their subject area. The method has been applied to bibliographic data bases on low-cost water supply and sanitation, yielding information for users and for the data base producers. © 1992 Akadémiai Kiadó.

Authors: Desmed A.
Title: New technologies in the belgian drinking water sector
Source title: Journal of the Chartered Institution of Water and Environmental Management
Affiliations: Assoc Natl des Services d'cau, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Desmed, A., Assoc Natl des Services d'cau, Belgium
Abstract: The internationalization of the European market means that the new technologies used in the Belgian water supply sector are very similar to those used in other European countries. Belgian experience of the following new technologies is described in this paper; dentitrification, automation, remote reading of water meters, network cartography, directional drilling, leak detection, and experiments with new materials and equipment.
Index Keywords: Water Distribution Systems - Leak Detection; Water Meters - Remote Reading; Water Pipelines - Maps; Water Treatment - Denitrification; Water Treatment Plants - Automation; Directional Driiling; Drinking Water Supply; Network Cartography; Water Supply

Authors: Lansens P., Meuleman C., Baeyens W.
Title: Long-term stability of methylmercury standard solutions in distilled, deionized water
Affiliations: Laboratorium voor Analytische Chemie, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, 1050 Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Lansens, P., Laboratorium voor Analytische Chemie, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, 1050 Brussels, Belgium; Meuleman, C., Laboratorium voor Analytische Chemie, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, 1050 Brussels, Belgium; Baeyens, W., Laboratorium voor Analytische Chemie, Vrije Universiteit Brussel, Pleinlaan 2, 1050 Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: The long-term storage behaviour of methylmercury at different concentrations in distilled, deionized water was studied under various storage conditions. The stability is strongly dependent on concentration, the container material and the storage temperature. Container pretreatment also has an influence. Light seems to have no effect on the stability of methylmercury solutions. © 1990.
Index Keywords: mercury; methylmercury; article; assay; nonhuman; standard; water pollution

Authors: Flemale A., Gillard C., Dierckx J.P.
Title: Comparison of central venous, oesophageal and mouth occlusion pressure with water-filled catheters for estimating pleural pressure changes in healthy adults
Affiliations: Department of Pneumology, Jumet City Hospital, 6040 Jumet, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Flemale, A., Department of Pneumology, Jumet City Hospital, 6040 Jumet, Belgium; Gillard, C., Department of Pneumology, Jumet City Hospital, 6040 Jumet, Belgium; Dierckx, J.P., Department of Pneumology, Jumet City Hospital, 6040 Jumet, Belgium
Abstract: The validity of the central venous and water-filled oesophageal catheter technique as a measure of pleural pressure changes was tested in ten healthy subjects in different body positions during inspiratory efforts with occluded airways, by comparing the simultaneous changes in mouth pressure (ΔPm) taken to represent pleural pressure changes, in central venous pressure (ΔPcv) and in oesophageal pressure (ΔPoes). ΔPcv/ΔPm values were close to unity in the sitting and left lateral positions, whereas in the supine and right lateral position, substantial deviations from unity were found in some instances. ΔPoes/ΔPm values were close to unity in all positions, except some rare instances. No appreciable phase difference between ΔPm/ΔPoes and ΔPm/ΔPcv was found when the amplitude ratios were close to unity. We conclude that valid measurements of pleural pressure changes can be obtained in most instances with the central venous and the water-filled oesophageal catheter system according to the occlusion test procedure.
Index Keywords: adult; central venous pressure; esophagus pressure; female; human; male; methodology; normal human; thorax pressure; Adult; Catheterization; Catheterization, Central Venous; Central Venous Pressure; Comparative Study; Esophagus; Female; Human; Male; Mouth; Pleura; Posture

Authors: Peeters E.-G.
Title: The possible influence of the components of the soil and the lithosphere on the development and growth of neoplasms
Affiliations: European Institute of Ecology and Cancer, INEC, 24bis rue des Fripiers, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Peeters, E.-G., European Institute of Ecology and Cancer, INEC, 24bis rue des Fripiers, Brussels, B-1000, Belgium
Abstract: The author reviews the background of the soil-cancer relationship. The study then goes into geocarcinogenic diseases in relation to soil composition, looking first at general factors: soil concentrations of selenium, caesiumrubidium-potassium, trace elements; natural radioactivity risks; cancer risks in connection with recycled waste water. In its final part, the study examines geocarcinogenic diseases linked with soil composition covering gastric cancer, cancer of the esophagus, urinary, breast, and bronchial cancer, pleural mesotheliomae and bone cancer. © 1987 Birkhäuser Verlag.
Author Keywords: cancer; geocarcinogenic diseases; geochemistry; pedology; selenium; Soil; water

Authors: De Pauw N., Roels D., Fontoura A.P.
Title: Use of artificial substrates for standardized sampling of macroinvertebrates in the assessment of water quality by the Belgian Biotic Index
Affiliations: Laboratory for Biological Research in Aquatic Pollution, State University of Ghent, J. Plateaustraat 22, Ghent, B-9000, Belgium; Institute of Zoology Dr. Augusto Nobre, University of Porto, Praça Gomes Teixeira, Porto, P-4000, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: De Pauw, N., Laboratory for Biological Research in Aquatic Pollution, State University of Ghent, J. Plateaustraat 22, Ghent, B-9000, Belgium; Roels, D., Laboratory for Biological Research in Aquatic Pollution, State University of Ghent, J. Plateaustraat 22, Ghent, B-9000, Belgium; Fontoura, A.P., Institute of Zoology Dr. Augusto Nobre, University of Porto, Praça Gomes Teixeira, Porto, P-4000, Portugal
Abstract: The paper reviews 3 years of experience in Belgium and Portugal with artificial substrates for collecting macroinvertebrates used in water quality assessment by means of the Belgian Biotic Index (B.B.I.). Artificial substrates provide a valid alternative method for sampling the macroinvertebrate fauna and the possibility of standardizing the sampling effort, whereas sampling with a handnet may be more subjective. Research has been focussed on the effect of sampler design and composition as well as conditions of exposure on the number of systematic units and the biotic index obtained. With artificial substrates correct assessments could be performed in different types of watercourses, including lowland brooks and canals as well as fast running upland rivers located in different climates. Guidelines for the development of a simple standard procedure with artificial substrates are proposed. © 1986 Dr W. Junk Publishers.
Author Keywords: artificial substrates; biotic index; macroinvertebrates; water quality assessment

Authors: Vandenborre H., Leysen R., Nackaerts H., Van der Eecken D., Van Asbroeck Ph., Smets W., Piepers J.
Title: Advanced alkaline water electrolysis using inorganic membrane electrolyte (I.M.E.) technology
Affiliations: Hydrogen Systems N.V., Jan Van Rijswijcklaan 17, B-2018 Antwerpen, Belgium; Studiecentrum voor Kernenergie, S.C.K., C.E.N., Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; N.V. Elektrische Nijverheidsinstallaties, E.N.I.S.A., Kontichse steenweg 25, B-2630 Aartselaar, Belgium; N.V. Bekaert S.A., Leo Bekaertstraat 1, B-8550 Zwevegem, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Vandenborre, H., Hydrogen Systems N.V., Jan Van Rijswijcklaan 17, B-2018 Antwerpen, Belgium; Leysen, R., Studiecentrum voor Kernenergie, S.C.K., C.E.N., Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Nackaerts, H., Studiecentrum voor Kernenergie, S.C.K., C.E.N., Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Van der Eecken, D., Studiecentrum voor Kernenergie, S.C.K., C.E.N., Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Van Asbroeck, Ph., Studiecentrum voor Kernenergie, S.C.K., C.E.N., Boeretang 200, B-2400 Mol, Belgium; Smets, W., N.V. Elektrische Nijverheidsinstallaties, E.N.I.S.A., Kontichse steenweg 25, B-2630 Aartselaar, Belgium; Piepers, J., N.V. Bekaert S.A., Leo Bekaertstraat 1, B-8550 Zwevegem, Belgium
Abstract: The Belgian Hydrogen Research Programme, aiming at the development of a new concept in advanced alkaline water electrolysis has resulted in demonstration projects with prototype electrolyser units. The new concept, named I.M.E. technology (inorganic membrane electrolyte) produces hydrogen under pressure (0.5-4.0 MPa) at current densities up to 12500 Am-2 and temperatures not exceeding 120°C. Electrocatalysts based on non-noble metals are deposited on perforated nickel plates. These electrodes are pressed against an inorganic ion-exchanger membrane based on polyantimonic acid. Circular cells (surface area up to 0.2 m2) are assembled in a filter-press type manner. Prototype electrolysers, having hydrogen production rate from 2.5 Nm3h-1 to 25 Nm3h-1 have been constructed and tested. Multicell performances (up to 60 unit cells) at 2000 Am-2 are 1.6 V at 90°C and even 1.5 V at 120°C. At a 5 times higher current density (10000 Am-2) cell voltages only increase with 0.3 V at 90°C and 0.2 V at 120°C. Since 100% Coulombic efficiency has been measured in these 60 unit cell stacks the electrical power consumption (at 2000 Am-2) per normal cubic meter of hydrogen produced is 3.81 kWh at 90°C and 3.65 kWh at 120°C. A techno-economic analysis was performed to quantify the cost of hydrogen as a function of design parameters such as module cost and module performance capability. © 1985.
Index Keywords: ELECTROLYTES; MEMBRANES - Applications; WATER - Electrolysis; ADVANCED ALKALINE WATER ELECTROLYSIS; ELECTROLYZERS; INORGANIC MEMBRANE ELECTROLYTE (I. M. E. ); MULTICELL STACKS; HYDROGEN
Funding Text 1: A Belgian research programme, aiming at the development of a new advanced concept in alkaline water electrolysis, has been carried out since 1976, at the Belgian Nuclear Research Centre (S.C.K./C.E.N.) Mol, under the auspices of the Commission of the European Communities in the framework of their Indirect Energy R&D programme, Sub-programme Hydrogen. As a result of the successful laboratory research, prototype electrolysers were built in collaboration with Belgian industries, with hydrogen production rate up to 25 Nm3h-1 . These advanced alkaline water eleetrolysers are based on the new concept, named inorganic membrane electrolyte (I.M.E.) technology [1-3]. The I.M.E. technology uses a patented separator composed of the inorganic ion-exchanger polyantimonic acid [4, 5] instead of the common asbestos separator. Electrocatalysts, based on non-noble metals are deposited on perforated nickel plates. These electrodes ,:ontact the inorganic ion-exchanger separator. Circular cells (surface area up to 0.2m2) are assembled in a filter-press type manner. The new I.M.E. technology concept produces hydrogen under pressure (0.5--4.0 MPa) at current densities ~p to 12500Am-2 and temperatures not exceeding ~20°C. Since 1983 two prototype electrolysers (hydrogen prod~ ,tion rate of 2.5 Nmath-1 and 25 Nm3h-1) have been constructed and are operating successfully, whereby the laboratory results were confirmed on both units.

Authors: Di Ferrante E.
Title: Cooperative research on water quality and health parameters in the European community
Affiliations: Commission of the European Communities, Brussels, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Di Ferrante, E., Commission of the European Communities, Brussels, Belgium
Abstract: Research programmes planned and sponsored by the Commission of the European Communities (CEC) are executed by the Joint Research Centre which belongs to the Community (direct action) and through the collaboration of research institutions of the member countries (indirect action). in the latter case national laboratories carry out investigations under contract with the CEC thus providing scientific and technological data needed in the implementation of Community policies in various fields such as Agriculture, Industrial Affairs, Energy, Environment. To sustain the Community policy on the environment, adopted in 1973, the CEC proposed and the Council of the EC approved, in parallel with direct action programmes, the first Environmental Research Programme of indirect action for the period 1973-1975 and the second Environmental Research Programme of indirect action for the period 1976-1980. Both programmes have contributed to improve the understanding of problems concerning the presence of pollutants in the environment and their ecological and health effects.
Funding Details: Joint Research Centre, JRC

Authors: Hubermont G., Buchet J.P., Roels H., Lauwerys R.
Title: Placental transfer of lead, mercury and cadmium in women living in a rural area - Importance of Drinking Water in Lead Exposure
Source title: International Archives of Occupational and Environmental Health
Affiliations: Unite de Toxicologic Industrielle et Medicale, 30, Clos Chapelle-aux-Champs, Brussels, B-1200, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Hubermont, G., Unite de Toxicologic Industrielle et Medicale, 30, Clos Chapelle-aux-Champs, Brussels, B-1200, Belgium; Buchet, J.P., Unite de Toxicologic Industrielle et Medicale, 30, Clos Chapelle-aux-Champs, Brussels, B-1200, Belgium; Roels, H., Unite de Toxicologic Industrielle et Medicale, 30, Clos Chapelle-aux-Champs, Brussels, B-1200, Belgium; Lauwerys, R., Unite de Toxicologic Industrielle et Medicale, 30, Clos Chapelle-aux-Champs, Brussels, B-1200, Belgium
Abstract: The influence of the lead content of drinking water on the transplacental transfer of lead was investigated in 70 pregnant women living in a rural area of Belgium. The mothers were divided into 2 groups: group A: morning water lead below 50 μg/liter; group B: morning water lead above this value. In group A, the mean lead content of water was 11.8 μg/liter and in group B it amounted to 247.4 μg/liter. The difference in the mean lead concentration between the two groups were for maternal blood: 3.2 μg/100 ml, for umbilical cord blood: 3.3 μg/100 ml, and for placenta: 3.6 μg/100 g. These differences are statistically significant. There were significant correlations between water lead and lead concentration in blood (mother, newborn) or placenta. An increment of water lead concentration from 50 to 500 μg/liter increases blood lead concentration in mother and in newborn by about 3 μg/100 ml and in placenta by about 2.5 μg/100 g (wet weight). © 1978 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Lead in maternal and foetal blood; Lead in placenta; Lead in water

Authors: Masschelein W.
Title: Health aspects of reagents used in water treatment (Dutch)
Affiliations: CIBE, Comp. Bruxelloise Eaux, Bruxelles, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Masschelein, W., CIBE, Comp. Bruxelloise Eaux, Bruxelles, Belgium
Abstract: The reagents and additives used or suggested in water treatment are presented in seven tables: products for disinfection and oxydation; for coagulation and flocculation; for pH correction and mineralisation; for improvement of water quality; adsorption products; flocculants and polyelectrolytes; and a table which lists products for cleaning installations. Each table contains the reagent, the suggested basic unit and the maximum treatment dose per m3. The procedure followed for obtaining permission for new products is outlined. Existing norms and guidelines are given. Further tables list guidelines with regard to trace elements in reagents. (25 references)
Index Keywords: adsorption; compound; disinfection; flocculation; methodology; toxicity; water standard; water treatment

Authors: Van Dijck P., De Jonckheere J., Reybrouck G., Van De Voorde H.
Title: Rapid indentification of Naegleria species by sero agglutination and fluorescent antibodies: new possibilities for the water supply services
Affiliations: Lab. Hyg., Kathol. Univ., Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Van Dijck, P., Lab. Hyg., Kathol. Univ., Leuven, Belgium; De Jonckheere, J., Lab. Hyg., Kathol. Univ., Leuven, Belgium; Reybrouck, G., Lab. Hyg., Kathol. Univ., Leuven, Belgium; Van De Voorde, H., Lab. Hyg., Kathol. Univ., Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Now and then, cases of primary meningo encephalitis caused by Naegleria are described, which occurred in several countries. These cases are related to the use of swimming pools. Swimming pools and even drinking water may contain amoebae, but their identification is painstaking and demands several months with the usual methods. Therefore the authors looked for a more rapid identification method by means of specific antisera. Antigens were prepared from Naegleria gruberi and N. fowleri strains in order to induce the formation of antibodies in rabbits for the identification of unknown amoebae by serological techniques. The antisera were obtained after three weekly injections of the antigen preparation. The formation of antibodies was demonstrated by agglutination and indirect fluorescence techniques. Agglutination titers of 1/320 to 1/640 were obtained. At the same titer, the fluorescence test was still positive. Cross reactions with a non homologous antigen are observed with low dilutions but not with the Hartmannella strain. Evans blue did not increase the specificity. Cysts react non specifically and a conversion to the amoebic state is necessary for the identification of unknown protozoa. The described serological techniques allow a sufficiently accurate identification of Naegleria in the field of public health and give an idea of the hazards linked with these or related genera.

Title: Does the presence of salmonella germs in sea water represent a real danger for public health? (Dutch)
Affiliations: Dept. Microbiol., Inst. Hyg. Epidemiol., Nat. Cent. Salmonella Shigella, Brussel, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Van Oye, E., Dept. Microbiol., Inst. Hyg. Epidemiol., Nat. Cent. Salmonella Shigella, Brussel, Belgium; Deleener, J., Dept. Microbiol., Inst. Hyg. Epidemiol., Nat. Cent. Epidemiol., Nat. Cent. Salmonella Shigella, Brussel, Belgium
Abstract: The sea water along the whole Belgian coast contains Salmonella germs, although in relatively small numbers. They demonstrate a microbial pollution, the sources of which should be found and abolished. This requires investigations on a much wider scale than is the case up to now, and which have to deal with problems of a more fundamental nature.

Authors: Poffe R.
Title: Water hygiene and environment. Some present day aspects [WATERHYGIENE EN MILIEU. ENKELE EIGENTIJDSE ASPECTEN]
Affiliations: Lab. Industr. Microbiol. Biochem., Kon. Univ., Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Poffe, R., Lab. Industr. Microbiol. Biochem., Kon. Univ., Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Per capita water use in Western Europe is very high, and in the U.S. even higher. This use is constantly increasing, and so new sources of water must be found. Tables give data for chemical pollution standards and a diagram shows the influences of natural and artificial pollution. Chemical parameters for fecal pollution are also given. The more common nonfecal pollutants are named, and their influence on health are described. Heavy metals, detergents and pesticides are discussed briefly. Artificial, deliberate additions to drinking water, such as fluoride, are mentioned and bacterial pollution is discussed with attention to the Standard Plate Count. A number of bacteria, such as the coli, streptococci and enterococci are examined individually. Viruses and protozoa are also mentioned and the author recommends a widespread measuring network to ensure water quality.
Index Keywords: environmental health

Authors: Lederer J.
Title: Is calcareous water detrimental to good health? [L'EAU CALCAIRE EST ELLE DESAVANTAGEUSE POUR LA SANTE?]
Affiliations: Lab. Nutrit., Ecole Sante Publ., Bruxelles, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Lederer, J., Lab. Nutrit., Ecole Sante Publ., Bruxelles, Belgium
Abstract: Contrary to wide spread preconceived notions, hard water with a high calcium content appears to offer protection against atheromatosis and infarction both in city and rural areas. Calcium may possibly intervene by preventing serious arrhythmias as a frequent cause of sudden death when infarction occurs.
Index Keywords: drinking water; atheroma; heart infarction; methodology; prevention; water hardness

Authors: Heyndrickx A.A.
Title: Environmental hygiene and pollution of air, water and soil [MILIEUHYGIENE EN LUCHT-, WATER- WATER EN BODEMVERONTREINIGING]
Affiliations: Fak. Farmaceut. Wetensch., Rijksuniv. Gent, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Heyndrickx, A.A., Fak. Farmaceut. Wetensch., Rijksuniv. Gent, Belgium
Abstract: The situation on air, water, and soil pollution in Belgium is described. Mention is made of the law of 1964, which has no enforcement due to a lack of Royal Decrees of application. A comparison is drawn with the situation in the neighbouring countries. The activities of the committees of Antwerp and East Flanders are summarized. An alternative solution is suggested, based upon a general legislation, which would be locally applied to protect the environment and public health.
Index Keywords: environmental health
